newsitem.title: USA: U.S. sweet crude grades advance in Thursday trade.
newsitem.headline: U.S. sweet crude grades advance in Thursday trade.

text.p: U.S. sweet crude grade differentials gained strength Thursday morning, shaving discounts to a firming outright cash price.
July West Texas Intermediate/Cushing was around 15 cents higher at $18.85-95 a barrel, compared to the futures screen price at $18.70 a barrel, 15 cents higher from Wednesday.
July EFPs were trading around 16-19 cents premium.
Sweet grades were led higher by Light Louisiana Sweet/St. James, which sold as firm as an 11 cents discount to the July WTI/Cushing cash, nine cents stronger than Wednesday.
"I would say it's short covering in LLS by foreign crude guys hedging against unsold foreign crude cargoes," said a cash player in Texas.
Refiners were not seen as being particularly active in the buy-up, the trader said.
Overall, July barrels look to be attracting more interest from buyers than in recent weeks.
"Margins are real good in the Med, and okay for northwest Europe, so there's been a general cleaning-up of some barrels. But, there are no shortages for August barrels," said a cash player.
Other trades were seen for Heavy Louisiana Sweet/Empire at 55 and 52 cents under WTI/Cushing, and for July Postings Plus at $1.80 and $1.83.
